Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Chemicals Inspection and Testing Institute; Biodegradation and bioaccumulation data of existing chemicals based on the CSCL Japan. Japan Chemical Industry Ecology - Toxicology and Information Center. ISBN 4-89074-101-1 (1992) (2) Park JH, Lee HJ; Chemosphere 26: 1905-16 (1993) (3) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Using carp (Cyprinus carpio) which were exposed over an 8-week period, the BCF of cyclohexane ranged from 31-102 at a concentration of 0.1 mg/L and 37-129 at a concentration of 0.01 mg/L(1). An experimental BCF of 158 has also been reported(2). According to a classification scheme(2), these BCF values suggest bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is moderate to high, provided the compound is not metabolized by the organism(SRC).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Xia G, Pignatello JJ; Environ Sci Technol 35: 84-94 (2001) (2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.11. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of June 11, 2014: https://www.epa.gov/oppt/exposure/pubs/episuitedl.htm (3) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 23 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Based on measured sorption isotherms in a high-organic soil(1), the Koc of cyclohexane can be estimated to be about 350(SRC). Using a structure estimation method based on molecular connectivity indices(2), the Koc for cyclohexane can be estimated to be about 150(SRC). According to a classification scheme(3), these estimated Koc values suggest that cyclohexane is expected to have moderate mobility in soil(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for cyclohexane has been measured as 0.15 atm-cu m/mole at 25 °C(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that cyclohexane is expected to volatilize rapidly from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 2.7 hours(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 3.6 days(SRC). Cyclohexane's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces may occur(SRC). Cyclohexane is expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 96.9 mm Hg(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: A contaminated drinking water well in New York contained 540 ppb of cyclohexane(1). A public drinking water supply in East Anglia, England that was 210 meters from a leaking petroleum storage tank contained 0.01 ppb cyclohexane and the groundwater 10 and 110 meters from the tank were 10 and <1 ppb, respectively(2). Cyclohexane was found in 5 of 14 waterworks sampled in the UK(3); the sources of the cyclohexane-tainted drinking water were rivers, reservoirs and groundwater, and the contaminate was present in raw, as well as treated water(3). Cyclohexane was detected in 20 of 86 bottled spring water samples, 1 of 61 bottled mineral water samples and 2 of 35 miscellaneous bottled waters in Canada in 1990 at average (range) concentrations of 42.2 (3-108), 3, and 27.6 (8.1-47) ug/kg, respectively(4). In a review of the open literature, cyclohexane was listed as one of the organic compounds most commonly found in drinking water wells(5); the highest concentration found was 540 ppb(5).

Reference: (1) Ewing BB et al; Monitoring to Detect Previously Unrecognized Pollut in Surface Waters USEPA-560/6-77-015 p. 75 (1977) (2) Sauer TC, JR; Org Geochem 3: 91-101 (1981) (3) Sauer TC, JR; Environ Sci Technol 15: 917-23 (1981) (4) Miermans CJH et al; Chemopshere 40: 39-48 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: In a survey of 14 heavily industrialized river basins in the United States (240 sites), 1 site in the Hudson River Basin contained 1 ppb of cyclohexane and 13 sites in the Mississippi River Basin contained 1.0-4.0 ppb of cyclohexane(1). Grab samples of surface water in the Gulf of Mexico in which there was anthopogenic influence contained 0-0.26 ppb of cyclohexane(2). Open water and unpolluted coastal water did not contain detectable quantities  of the chemical(2). Surface water at an offshore oil production operation in the Gulf of Mexico contained 0.47 ppb of cyclohexane(3). Cyclohexane concentrations of <0.1 to 1.6 ug/L were reported for surface waters of the Dutch Rhine, Meuse, Northern Delta area and Westerscheldt over the period of 1991-1997(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: In a comprehensive survey of wastewater from 4000 industrial and publicly owned treatment works sponsored by the Effluent Guidelines Division of the USEPA, cyclohexane was identified in discharges of the following industrial categories (frequency of occurrence; median concentration in ppb): timber products (3;23.0), petroleum refining (7;46.0), coal mining (3;20.0), organics and plastics (33;14.0), inorganic chemicals (9;267.0), textile mills (3; 6.0), plastics and synthetics (2;6.0), rubber processing (5;125.0), auto and other laundries (1;3.0), pesticides manufacture (5; 48.0) photographic industry (1;47.0), pharmaceuticals(1;3.0), oil and gas extraction (7;4.0), mechanical products (1;7.0), and publicly owned treatment works (14;6.0)(1). Cyclohexane was one of the volatile organic hydrocarbons emitted from simulated municipal landfills(2). These "simulated landfills" consisted of steel tanks packed with municipal waste and various loading rates of municipal wastewater sludge. Analysis started 8 months after loading and continued for a year. Cyclohexane sampled in formation water and in an underwater vent plume at an offshore oil production operation in the Gulf of Mexico was 100 ppb and 1 umol/1 of gas, respectively(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: The average emission of cyclohexane from gasoline in S. California, 1987, was 0.37% of the total non-methane hydrocarbon concentration(1); in Chicago, 1990, it was 0.7%(2). Cyclohexane emissions were found to be 0.4% and 0% of total organic emission for catalyst and non-catalyst auto engines, respectively(3). It was detected in exhaust of 1975-1982 model passenger vehicles(4). Cyclohexane was detected as an emission from Oklahoma oil fields, 1988, at an average concentration of 2.1 ppbC(5). The emissions of wastewater sludge composting facility contained cyclohexane at a concentration of 327 ug/cu m(6). The average concentration of cyclohexane in the exhaust of 6 cars in the UK, 1988, was 82 ppb(7). Cyclohexane was qualitatively detected as an emission from 5 hazardous waste sites and a landfill in NJ, date not provided(8). Cyclohexane was qualitatively detected in 39/81 categories of common household products(9,10). Cyclohexane emissions have been associated with architectural and industrial coatings(1) and gasoline refineries(2). Cyclohexane was detected at concentrations of 4-31 mg/cu m in landfill gas emissions at 7 sites in the United Kingdom(11). Monitoring of vehicle emissions in road tunnels of Sao Paulo, Brazil in 2004 detected a mean cyclohexane emission factor of 81.3 mg/km(12).

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: The concentration of cyclohexane in Tulsa, OK on July 27, 1978 was 0-3.30 ppbC (ppb carbon) whereas at a rural site 37 km downwind it was 2.70 ppbC(1). StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Cyclohexane was detected in 37.5% of the samples collected in Washington, DC, March 1991, at a mean and maximum concentrations of 0.42 and 10.8 ppbV, respectively(1). It was detected in 9 or 12 rural air samples in LA, 1990, at concentrations ranging from 0.3 to 1.5 ppbV(2). Cyclohexane was detected at an average concentration of approximately 2 ppbC in Atlanta air samples, Aug-Sep, 1992(3). Based on measurements from 39 US cities, 1984-85, the atmospheric concentration of cyclohexane ranged from 0.2 to 409 ppbC with a median concentration of 2.2 ppbC(4). The average concentration of cyclohexane in roadway samples near Raleigh, NC, 1983, was 0.39% of the total non-methane hydrocarbon concentration(5). Cyclohexane was detected in 120 of 129 samples collected across Canada, Nov 90 to Dec 91, at concentrations ranging from 0.01 to 0.12 ppbV(6). The average concentration of cyclohexane at street level in London, 1988, was 2.3 ppb(7). Cyclohexane was qualitatively found in 4 of 8 personal air samples of subjects monitored in Bayonne and Elizabeth, NJ, and Research Triangle Park, NC, 1980(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: According to the VOC national ambient database, updated in 1986, cyclohexane was detected in 4 indoor air samples ranging from 0.4 to 2.3 ppbv with an average concentration of 1.38 ppbV(1). Cyclohexane was detected in new or recently renovated buildings in Switzerland, at a maximum concentration of 7162 ug/cu m(2). Cyclohexane was qualitatively detected in houses that had recently used an oil-based floor finish(3). The mean concentration of cyclohexane in indoor air of 3 Italian cities, March, 1995, was 4.5, 5.7, and 5.6 ug/cu m(4). Cyclohexane concentrations of 340-380 ug/cu m were detected in living room and bedroom air of homes in Melbourne, Australia 2 days after construction(5); concentrations fell to <1 ug/cu 17 days later(5). A mean cyclohexane concentration of 2.90 ug/cu (maximum concentration 52 ug/cu m) was detected in indoor air of homes in suburban and rural New Jersey(6). Cyclohexane was detected (detection limit of 0.015 ug/cu m) in indoor air samples at 70 of 75 homes in Ottawa, Canada during winter 2002-2003 monitoring at a concentration range of 0.015-54.12 ug/cu m (mean concentration of 6.58 ug/cu m)(7).

Reference: (1) Arnts RR, Meeks S; Biogenic Hydrocarbon Contribution to the Ambient Air of Selected Areas USEPA-600/3-80-023 (1980) (2) Seila RL; Non-Urban Hydrocarbon Concn in Ambient Air North of Houston, Texas USEPA-500/3-79-0 10 (1979) (3) Hov O et al; Geophys Res Lett 11: 425-8 (1984) (4) Fuentes JD et al; J Atmos Chem 25: 67-95 (1996) (5) Brown SK; Indoor Air 12: 55-63 (2002) (6) Zhu J et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 3964-3971 (2005)

StringWithMarkup.String: RURAL/REMOTE: Cyclohexane concentration in air samples from Rio Blanco County, CO July, 1978 was 0.10-0.60 ppb-C(1); Smokey Mountain National Park, Sept, 1978 was 0-1.20 ppbC(1). Cyclohexane concentration in air samples from Jones State Forest, TX Jan, 1978 was 0.3 to 3.3 ppb-C, 2.5 ppbC mean(2). Concentrations of 9 samples of air from the Norwegian Arctic (July 1982) were <20 parts per trillion while 10 samples (Spring 1983) average 54 parts per trillion(3). The concentration of cyclohexane above a forest in southern Ontario, 1993, was approximately 0.1 ppbv(4). Outdoor air samples sampled in Melborne, Australia were <5.0 ug/cu m(5). Cyclohexane was detected (detection limit of 0.015 ug/cu m) in outdoor air samples at 70 of 75 homes in Ottawa, Canada during winter 2002-2003 monitoring at a concentration range of 0.015-32.80 ug/cu m (mean concentration of 1.98 ug/cu m)(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 55,078 workers (14,872 of these were female) were potentially exposed to cyclohexane in the US(1). Occupational exposure to cyclohexane may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where cyclohexane is produced or used(SRC). The general population may be exposed to cyclohexane via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of drinking water, and dermal contact with consumer products containing cyclohexane. The general population may also be exposed to cyclohexane due to its presence in gasoline(SRC).
